Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Non-Destructive Fatigue Monitoring System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase 1 project proposes to develop an advanced non-contact, non-destructive monitoring technology to reliably identify early fatigue damage in pipelines, piping, and tubing. Current industry practice relies on statistically based, semi-empirical models that unfortunately can have an order of magnitude in error in predicting fatigue life, a leading failure mode in metals that are exposed to high cycling, high strain, and/or elevated pressures and temperatures. The United States infrastructure relies on millions of miles of pipes, pipelines, and tubing that are critical in the transport of valuable fluids serving a number of industries including municipal water, production and transport of oil and gas, and chemicals in processing plants. Unfortunately, this aging infrastructure can fail with disastrous consequences.
The successful development and commercialization of this new technology will be a great leap in integrity monitoring, resulting in significant reduction in costs and delays, and eliminating catastrophic failures in the field. The estimated total addressable market for pipeline and coil tubing monitoring are in excess of $4 billion annually.

The intellectual merit of this SBIR project centers on the demonstration of the technical and economic feasibility of this novel fatigue monitoring technology with a specific target of identifying when the material has reached 90% of its actual fatigue life. The technology is based on a novel electromagnetic measurement scheme that can effectively detect magnetic dislocations in the material which have been shown to be early indicators of failure due to fatigue. Using advanced analytics, strong correlations between the measured electromagnetic properties and fatigue life can provide a direct and reliable identifier of imminent fatigue damage without loss of material integrity. The major challenges that this SBIR effort proposes to address are (1) engineering an electromagnetic-based measurement technique with sufficient sensitivity to detect the magnetic defects seen in early fatigue damage under field operating conditions (2) developing appropriate detection algorithms to handle the statistical variations affecting fatigue damage and (3) engineering a cost-effective monitoring solutions compared with alternative fatigue management practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We researched the effectiveness of a proposed method to monitor fatigue in metal pipes in hopes of developing a reliable identifier of imminent failure without loss of material integrity.  The method is based on non-destructive electromagnetic measurements of the relative changes to the magnetic permeability and hysteresis of the base material as it is fatigued to failure. Theoretical analysis and experimental testing on 2 inch carbon steel and stainless steel tubing were undertaken to investigate the sensitivity of the proposed technique.  We found that, in carbon steel, the magnetic properties changed ~10% with the first fatigue cycle and remained relatively constant within the measurement noise up until failure. In 304 stainless steel, the magnetic properties changed monotonically with fatigue but sample to sample variation was ~60%. In 316 stainless steel, the magnetic properties varied more inconsistently with fatigue than 304 stainless steel.  

Within the measurement parameters of the current research, the proposed method does not show any improvement of detecting fatigue damage over existing methods.  Our results suggest that the magnetic properties of the tubing are dominated by the Villari effect which is the change to the magnetic susceptibility when subjected to mechanical stress.  Changes in the magnetic domains due to fatigue may be small compared to the Villari effect. This could be amplified by the different stress conditions of the experiments and variation in local stress conditions as the tubing is fatigued and becomes warped.  Furthermore, there is a trade off between spatial sensitivity and measurement practicality.  The current design of the solenoid assembly averages the magnetic properties over the entire volume of tubing contained within the solenoid.  Imminent failure may not be detected sufficiently early depending on the relative size of the fatigue damaged zone. Smaller, more sensitive probes can be constructed but also introduces more instrument complexity and longer required measurement time.  Future work could focus on higher sensitivity techniques specifically on 304 stainless steels.


Last Modified: 08/08/2018
Modified by: Scott Nguyen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We researched the effectiveness of a proposed method to monitor fatigue in metal pipes in hopes of developing a reliable identifier of imminent failure without loss of material integrity. The method is based on non-destructive electromagnetic measurements of the relative changes to the magnetic permeability and hysteresis of the base material as it is fatigued to failure. Theoretical analysis and experimental testing on 2 inch carbon steel and stainless steel tubing were undertaken to investigate the sensitivity of the proposed technique. We found that, in carbon steel, the magnetic properties changed ~10% with the first fatigue cycle and remained relatively constant within the measurement noise up until failure. In 304 stainless steel, the magnetic properties changed monotonically with fatigue but sample to sample variation was ~60%. In 316 stainless steel, the magnetic properties varied more inconsistently with fatigue than 304 stainless steel. Within the measurement parameters of the current research, the proposed method does not show any improvement of detecting fatigue damage over existing methods. Our results suggest that the magnetic properties of the tubing are dominated by the Villari effect which is the change to the magnetic susceptibility when subjected to mechanical stress. Changes in the magnetic domains due to fatigue may be small compared to the Villari effect. This could be amplified by the different stress conditions of the experiments and variation in local stress conditions as the tubing is fatigued and becomes warped. Furthermore, there is a trade off between spatial sensitivity and measurement practicality. The current design of the solenoid assembly averages the magnetic properties over the entire volume of tubing contained within the solenoid. Imminent failure may not be detected sufficiently early depending on the relative size of the fatigue damaged zone. Smaller, more sensitive probes can be constructed but also introduces more instrument complexity and longer required measurement time. Future work could focus on higher sensitivity techniques specifically on 304 stainless steels. Last Modified: 08/08/2018 Submitted by: Scott Nguyen
